title: Dynamic Interactive Story Engine
description:
Build an InkJS-based narrative engine that enables rapid creation of immersive, story-first games, starting with an Ink-powered text-only MVP (M1) and evolving through AI-assisted branching toward a reactive simulated world.

- Problem
  - We need an engine that makes it fast and repeatable to create dynamic, immersive narrative games, with a roadmap toward AI-assisted branching and world reactivity.
  - The repository currently lacks a clear runtime-ready vertical slice (story runtime + player UX + save/load + runtime telemetry) that can be iterated in small focused loops.

- Users
  - Players: narrative-focused players (15–45 minute sessions) on desktop/mobile browsers.
  - Creators (internal initially): Producer using AI assistance to generate initial Ink content for demos (future: writers/designers).

- Success criteria (M1 / MVP)
  - Runtime story play: InkJS runtime loads and executes one Ink story end-to-end (branching choices at runtime) with no fatal runtime errors; demo story completes.
  - Player UX: player can select choices; single-slot save/load works (autosave + manual save).
  - Performance: first story screen cold start ≤ 8s on desktop browsers and ≤ 12s on mobile browsers (targets are measurable and can be tuned later if needed).
  - Observability: runtime telemetry events emitted for story start, choice selected, and story completion.
  - Content: at least 1 AI-generated demo story is included and playable.

- Constraints
  - Runtime: InkJS (Node / browser).
  - Content source (M1): AI creates demo Ink story content.
  - Timeline: undefined / not fixed.
  - Telemetry: must work at runtime (design-time-only telemetry is insufficient).
  - Ownership: Producer (you) is owner/assignee for this epic.
  - Non-goals (M1): none specified (explicitly).

- Existing state (if applicable)
  - No existing beads found that represent this engine epic; any current open bead(s) appear unrelated.
  - No existing runtime Ink integration artifacts were found during high-level scanning (if they exist, Producer should point to the location).

- Desired change (if applicable)
  - Establish the initial “vertical slice” narrative runtime using InkJS (Ink runtime + minimal UI + save/load + runtime telemetry) to enable rapid iteration, and provide a baseline to expand toward AI-assisted branching and, later, a simulated world.

- Milestones (suggested; editable)
  - M0 (Scaffold / smoke demo): browser-based scaffold that can display static text panels and advance pages; basic UI layout works on desktop browsers and mobile.
  - M1 (MVP): fully scripted, text-only interactive novel using Ink at runtime:
    - branching choices, save/load (single slot), runtime telemetry, 1 playable demo story.
  - M1.5 (Content iteration loop): workflow/tooling to rapidly swap stories + basic automated story regression replays (e.g., “golden path” replays).
  - M2: scripted story with AI-generated branches:
    - AI proposes branches within constraints; guardrails to prevent incoherent/unsafe output; runtime can integrate generated branches.
  - M3: basic 2D backgrounds + 3D posed characters:
    - story beats can trigger staging (background swap, character pose, simple animation cues).
  - M4: simulated world reacting to player actions while following scripted arc:
    - world state model + AI adaptation that preserves a high-level authorial arc; player agency feels real while narrative remains guided.
  - M5 (optional / advanced): richer interaction + systemic characters:
    - NPC goals/memory, quest/state graphs, and a narrative “director” steering toward story arcs.

- Related issues (Beads ids)
  - None identified as directly related.

- Recommended next step
  - PRD: docs/prd/GDD_M1_dynamic_interactive_story_engine.md

- Risks & assumptions (notes)
  - Ink runtime integration risk: runtime APIs may require glue code or adaptation.
  - Telemetry gap: design-time telemetry exists; runtime telemetry may need new plumbing and event schema decisions.
  - Browser constraints: memory/CPU budgets may force design constraints; early profiling may be needed.
  - AI-generated content quality/safety: outputs may be incoherent or unsuitable; need guardrails and provenance/versioning later.
  - Save compatibility: changes to story structure may break existing saves; define expectations early.

title: M0 — Scaffold / Smoke Demo
description:
M0 — Scaffold / Smoke Demo

Minimal browser-based scaffold proving VN-style text UI and a working InkJS dev path.

## Scope
Create a small browser-based scaffold that proves the InkJS runtime dev path and produces a smoke demo playable in desktop and mobile browsers. The scaffold should be simple HTML/JS using a fork of InkJS to load and run an Ink story (a short demo story should be included). Suggested repository location: web/ or demo/.

This task is documentation/text-only for the M0 scaffold description. Do not modify Unity project files, .unity scenes, C# source, or binary assets in this issue. If a sibling bead references a code or binary artifact that must be changed, handle that with a discovered-from follow-up bead (do not edit the artifact here).

## Success Criteria
- Demo loads and executes an Ink story end-to-end in a desktop browser and in a mobile browser viewport (no fatal runtime errors).
- Branching choices present and selectable at runtime.
- Single-slot save/load implemented and demonstrable (e.g., localStorage or downloadable save file).
- Developer instructions included describing how to run the demo locally (example: cd web && npm ci && npm start or open demo/index.html).
- Minimal telemetry hook points are documented (story_start, choice_selected, story_complete). Implementation of telemetry can be deferred to follow-ups, but hooks and example calls must be visible in the demo docs.

## Dependencies
- None (this is a docs/scaffold definition). Any implementation work that touches code or binaries should be managed by separate follow-up beads.

## Deliverables
- Updated M0 scaffold description and success criteria (this issue).
- Suggested demo location noted (web/ or demo/) and basic developer run instructions.
- bd comment (by implementer) listing any doc files updated and a short rationale.

title: Implement: Smoke
description:
Finalized intake & implementation plan

Context & decisions
- Target runtime: Browser / InkJS (use Producer's fork if present). The smoke effect will be triggered by an Ink story cue in the demo (Ink-driven first pass).
- File layout: place a minimal static demo under web/demo/ (index.html + js + assets). No full npm project required for the first pass; keep layout simple so demo can be opened in a browser.
- Placeholder assets: acceptable. Use procedural/CSS/Canvas visuals or small PNGs where necessary.
- Remote: no origin configured; all work will be implemented locally on branch feature/ge-hch.1.2.2-smoke and paused before any push.

Acceptance criteria (testable)
1) Demo loads in desktop and mobile browser viewports without fatal errors.
2) InkJS story loads and runs; the story includes a cue that triggers the smoke visual (e.g., a tag or a specially-formatted line).
3) Smoke visual appears when triggered and respects configurable parameters: duration (default 2–4s) and intensity.
4) Demo supports single-slot save/load via localStorage preserving story position and whether smoke has been triggered.
5) Telemetry hooks (console-visible) are present and called: story_start, smoke_triggered, story_complete.
6) Dev run instructions included in docs/InkJS_README.md explaining how to open the demo locally and where the Ink story lives.

Minimal implementation plan (high-level tasks)
- web/demo/ skeleton + InkJS integration: load InkJS (forked), load web/stories/demo.ink, run story start and wire story events to demo hooks.  (priority: 1)
- Smoke visual & trigger: implement smoke visual in JS/Canvas/CSS, and wire trigger to an Ink cue emitted by the story. (priority: 1, depends on skeleton)
- Save/load: single-slot localStorage API to store story state (canonical story position + smoke state). (priority: 1, depends on skeleton)
- Docs: docs/InkJS_README.md updated with run instructions, telemetry hook examples, and demo file list. (priority: 2)

Deliverables (planned files)
- web/demo/index.html
- web/demo/js/inkrunner.js (small wrapper to load InkJS and story)
- web/demo/js/smoke.js
- web/stories/demo.ink
- web/demo/assets/* (small placeholders)
- docs/InkJS_README.md (update or create)

Open operational notes
- Keep all changes local until a remote is provided. I will not push or create a PR until you give a remote/permission.
- Implementation should be executed by the implementation agent per the plan above; Map will coordinate and create follow-ups as required.

Next step
- Create implementation subtasks and hand off to an implementation owner to implement and validate.
